{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3534832,"name":"Rowan Flood","username":"rflood","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/7bcc69/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-20T23:50:30.876Z","cooked":"

Hello everyone!

I am the lead programmer for Team 2491 NoMythic, and this year we are running an elevator with two end effectors: an algae end effector and a coral end effector.

Elevator Setup

  • Structure: Three-stage continuous elevator, spanning 20 cm to 200 cm off the ground.
  • Motors: Controlled by two Krakens (TalonFX motor controllers).
  • Control Method: Motion Magic with the following configs:
    • Cruise Velocity: 600 cm/s
    • Acceleration: 2400 cm/s²
    • PID Constants:
      • kP: 0.4
      • kG: 0.57
      • kA: 0.00040067
      • kV: 0.02168
      • kS: 1.17
      • (Other constants are blank)

Issue We’re Seeing

We noticed a strange voltage discrepancy when graphing the Motor Voltage in Phoenix Tuner X:

  • On the way up (e.g., from 40 cm → 180 cm), the motor voltage stays around 4V for most of the motion.
  • On the way down (e.g., from 180 cm → 40 cm), the motor voltage increases to around 6V.
  • This difference in voltage varies based on the distance of the setpoint change.

Why This is a Problem

This makes tuning difficult because:

  1. We can’t increase the upward speed without making the downward speed too fast.
  2. The 4V on the way up isn’t enough to move the elevator as quickly as we’d like.

Troubleshooting So Far

  • We’ve verified that kG is applied correctly (i.e., positive voltage moves the elevator up).
  • However, we’re still unsure why more voltage is being applied when moving downward.

Question

Does anyone with Motion Magic & TalonFX tuning experience know what could be causing this? Are there any common issues that lead to higher voltage when moving down than up?

Any insights would be greatly appreciated! Thanks in advance.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-02-20T23:51:45.901Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":68,"reads":98,"readers_count":97,"score":359.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":492517,"topic_slug":"motion-magic-voltage-issue-on-elevator-help-needed","display_username":"Rowan Flood","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":73641,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/motion-magic-voltage-issue-on-elevator-help-needed/492517/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3534904,"name":"Carl Hauser","username":"chauser","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/a587f6/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-21T01:06:53.356Z","cooked":"

We have a similar elevator with Falcon500s and TalonFXs, also using motion magic. It’s impossible to tell whether most of your k* constants make sense without knowing the units. But it seems reasonable to guess that kS is in volts and that seems quite high to me as it says it takes almost 1/10 of the full-voltage output of two Krakens to move your elevator against friction.

I’ll give you our numbers for comparison but you must take into accounts the units before any comparison will be useful. Note we have our ratios set, taking into account various gear and chainwheel sizes, so that control constants are directly in terms of meters
kS = 0.04 volts
kV = 1.9 volts/(meter/sec)
kA = 0.08 volts/(meter/sec^2)
kG = 0.44 volts
kP = 38.2
kD = 1.55
(I don’t know off the top of my head whether the kP and kD are in terms of position error or velocity error for position motion magic so I didn’t give units for those).

The moving mass of the elevator is 4Kg.
MM cruise velocity is 300cm/sec, and acceleration is 1500cm/sec^2.

I was planning to confirm tonight that the cruise and acceleration targets are being achieved. But I can say that with this setup the elevator motion is fast enough to be unsettling in its speed and that it achieves its setpoints almost perfectly.

There is one other thing that we discovered that may be relevant. We have one motor commanded to act as a follower of the other (with inversion, of course). We discovered that if you issue a different command to the follower it stops following. So we had our stop method as m_leftMotor.set(0); m_rightMotor.set(0); the result was that the elevator would go fast the first time a MM setControl was given but after that it was much slower since the right motor had stopped following the left. Now for stop we just do m_leftMotor.setControl(m_neutralOut) where m_neutralOut is initialized to a NeutralOut control.

By the way, the feedforward and feedback constants were all determined using sysID on a simulation of the elevator. I am somewhat flabbergasted that this worked, but we have not seen any reason to change them given that they work so well.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-02-21T01:06:53.356Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":83,"readers_count":82,"score":71.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":492517,"topic_slug":"motion-magic-voltage-issue-on-elevator-help-needed","display_username":"Carl Hauser","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":36833,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/motion-magic-voltage-issue-on-elevator-help-needed/492517/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3534919,"name":"Carl Hauser","username":"chauser","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/a587f6/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-21T01:12:01.277Z","cooked":"

Oh, one other thing. The elevator is geared so that 18 motor revolutions correspond to 1 meter of elevator travel. Those are really powerful motors!

And I should also say that the motors’ gearboxes are connected with a common shaft which I think is really important to avoid twisting things out of shape by imperfectly matching the travel of the left and right sides of the elevator.

chauser:

I am somewhat flabbergasted that this worked, but we have not seen any reason to change them given that they work so well.

This is basically a very roundabout way of getting the same theoretical values that ReCalc would give you

Yeah. The elevator simulation was developed for other reasons (designing the control logic for handoffs and the like) as well as practicing with SysID. When I saw that the numbers from SysID pretty much agreed with the ReCalc numbers I just went with them.
